Date of the arrest and update regarding Moynihan’s threat against Hakeem Jeffries, indicating ongoing public safety concerns related to political threats.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from the January 6 Capitol attack to the 2025 arrest highlights a persistent threat environment involving former January 6 defendants, especially those pardoned by President Trump.

keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former January 6 Capitol rioter, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously convicted of obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct at the Capitol, sentenced to nearly two years in prison.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan in early 2025 as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.

Moynihan allegedly stated in a text message that he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and expressed homicidal ideations, with law enforcement citing potential drug abuse and mental health concerns.
A New York judge ruled that Moynihan remains in prison pending trial on a terroristic threat charge, with no attorneys listed and no family reached.
The threat comes amid heightened national concern over political assassinations, such as the recent killing of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.
Moynihan's prior history includes opiate addiction and misdemeanor convictions related to substance use and petty larceny.
Before the Capitol incident, Moynihan was politically engaged online during the Trump presidency, suggesting ideological alignment with far-right political movements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former January 6 Capitol rioter convicted of obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct, was arrested in October 2025 for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in the year, Moynihan remained in prison pending trial on a terroristic threat charge, following allegations that he stated in a text message he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and expressed homicidal ideations. Law enforcement cited concerns over drug abuse and mental health, and Moynihan’s past addiction history and political engagement online during the Trump era are highlighted. The incident occurs amid national anxiety over political violence, following the recent assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk, reinforcing fears about threats against public officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
